results.title: Child survival alliance
results.brief_description: Looks at Colombia’s massive attempt to immunize all its children. Three days a year are set aside by the government to give the children vaccines against polio, diptheria, whooping cough, tetanus and measles.

results.title: Child soldiers [Widescreen] (D)
results.creator_credit: Andrew Ogilvie, Alan Lindsay, OPB, ABC-TV (Australia), ScreenWest and Electric Pictures (Aust)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big picture”.
This is an extremely disturbing documentary on the use and abuse of children as young as 10 years old being recruited as child soldiers by various means - voluntary or involuntary - through abduction, intimidation, coercion, or exploitation of a child’s social circumstances. More than thirty nations globally participate in this barbaric and inhumane practice involving over 300,000 children (conservative estimate by the United Nations) who are brutalised, drugged, brainwashed, and indoctrinated to kill and commit atrocities in civil wars and armed conflict. From Southern Sudan to Uganda, Burma, Columbia and Sierra Leone we are confronted with some of these young soldiers (girls as well as boys) and their horrific accounts of life as a child soldier. Many tell of their dangerous attempts at escape, returning home, only to be kidnapped again and again. However even more distressing is the enormous challenge these ex child soldiers have to face in overcoming the abuse and trauma which they have suffered, both physically and psychologically. Many of them end up homeless, too frightened to return home. And it is not only third world countries who recruit underage soldiers. The US recruit 17 year olds and Great Britain has no hesitation in sending 16 year olds off to war. Both the United Nations and the International Criminal Court are trying to resolve this human crisis but it is going to be a long hard struggle and in the meantime tragically, hundreds of thousands of young children worldwide are pawns in an adult game of violence and conflict. Narrated by Anthony LaPaglia. NOTE: CONTAINS MANY VISUALLY DISTURBING IMAGES.

results.title: Child Self Esteem
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PGR Series”.
In this title we commence by differentiating between self concept and self-esteem. We discuss how by the age of two, a child has a well developed self concept. The crucial role of parents in the development of a child’s self-esteem is discussed, and we show how an understanding of child development is helpful in fostering good self-esteem in a child. We use dramatisations to show how parental behaviours influence child self-esteem, and conclude by discussing with two parents changes they made in their approach to their children.

results.title: Child psychiatry: autism's lonely children
results.creator_credit: David Prowitt, National Educational Television, Philip Burton and Jack Willis
results.brief_description: Explains the work of Dr. Frank Hewett in teaching autistic children to talk and identify objects. Shows work with a child and Dr. Hewett attempting to transfer to the child’s parents techniques used successfully to evoke responses. Discusses the possible effectiveness of the approach on other autistic children.

results.title: Child of urban Thailand: a place to live
results.creator_credit: South Pacific Television, World Vision of New Zealand and Don Whyte
results.brief_description: Highlights a day in the life of a ten-year-old boy who lives in the slums of Bangkok, Thailand. Examines the problems of rural people who have moved to the city without job skills or money. Motivates discussion about the rights and responsibilities of children in different types of family and community situations. Helps to build understanding and appreciation of other cultures. Stimulates concern for children who are denied basic rights and opportunities. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Child of the Philippines: no time to play
results.creator_credit: Bryan H. Easte, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Don Whyte
results.brief_description: Highlights a day in the life of an eleven year old girl who lives in a back country village of the Philippines, and who has to work before and after an eleven hour school day. Explores the problem of children deprived of the basic right to adequate rest and relaxation.

results.title: Child of the future: how he might learn
results.brief_description: Education is increasingly affected by technological advances. Shows how schools and colleges are shedding their traditional apathy to machines and are now exploiting all manner of mechanical and electronic aids and how these changes affect the child. Several leading educators and innovators including Dr. Marshall McLuhan and Dr. Jerome Bruner of Havard University discuss the ways traditional practice is adapting to radical new methods.

results.title: Child molestation: when to say no
results.creator_credit: Charles Cahill and Associates, Dana Young and Elizabeth Young
results.brief_description: Uses four dramatisations to illustrate typical encounters between a child and a child molester. Shows the child how to thwart the attempt of molestation and stresses the importance of reporting such incidents to a responsible adult. Suitable for middle and upper primary school levels.
